{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3341063,"name":null,"username":"LeBotJames1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/ce73a5/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T00:50:56.178Z","cooked":"

My team has a rotating arm that controls our shooting angle. Currently, we are using encoder values to track arm position, but we are having issues with consistency due to slack in the chain and overall wear and tear. Are there other, more accurate, ways to track rotation/angle? Right now, we are thinking of implementing PID but have little experience and have run into issues in the past. Are potentiometers easy to implement? If so, where should we get one from?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-23T00:50:56.178Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":134.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65323,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3341066,"name":"Dan Langdon","username":"woodworker2001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/bbe5ce/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T00:55:09.363Z","cooked":"

Absolute encoder attached directly to the arm. Cancoder or rev through bore would be the two most common

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-23T00:55:09.363Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":241,"readers_count":240,"score":98.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":"Dan Langdon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51496,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3341205,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T05:30:42.526Z","cooked":"

Helium canandcoder and thrifty absolute encoder are the two newer options.

Potentiometers are generally not used, I think because resistance can vary between devices and over time/with usage.

A picture of the arm setup would allow people to give more specific advice. If you can reduce backlash by tightening your chain, or if you increase the size of the arm sprocket, you may be able to get decent results even with the integrated encoder (though never as good as the absolute encoder).

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-23T05:34:42.583Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51496,"username":"woodworker2001","name":"Dan Langdon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/bbe5ce/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/3","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3341290,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T13:34:45.453Z","cooked":"

If you don’t have a good way of attaching an encoder, I’ve seen some teams use a set of 3d printed gears (usually with a helical tooth profile) to get the encoder mounted with little backlash.

If the drive is really unsteady a different route would be to use a lidar or ultrasonic to measure position of a location on the arm.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T21:30:58.005Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":19.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":"EricRehder","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342086,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T22:20:19.880Z","cooked":"

Our arm is controlled by a SparkMax speed controller and we have a REV through bore encoder on the axle.

Our arm doesn’t go lower than 10 degrees and no higher than 125 degrees so we don’t have to deal with negative arm angles.

On robot start up we look at the REV TB encoder and use the value to set the position of the SparkMax encoder to the correct value. Then we just use the SparkMax positional PID to set our arm angle.

We have about 4 degrees of chain slop but since that’s mechanical there’s nothing you can do programmatically.

We turn on the robot when the arm is near 45 degrees and the arm will hit set angles. But because of chain slop when the arm passes over 90 deg the angle we set via SparkMax will not match the physical angle of the arm. So when we tell the arm to go to 110 the SparkMax will say we are at 110 but the REV TB encoder will show 114.
But that’s ok since it is consistent. We just determined all our angles experimentally.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T22:20:19.880Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":"AfterTen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/6","custom_user_title":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342089,"name":"ben gates","username":"banjogates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T22:28:08.569Z","cooked":"

Avoid REV thrubores, they are fragile and can have incorrect readouts. Stick with a CTRE mag encoder direct mounted to the axle

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T22:28:08.569Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459766,"topic_slug":"ways-to-track-arm-position","display_username":"ben gates","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"breh"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-track-arm-position/459766/7","custom_user_title":"breh","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342106,"name":"Kevin Furlong","username":"dewmaster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T23:05:00.756Z","cooked":"

We didn’t have an easy way to attach an encoder to our arm last year, so we put a spare Pigeon 2 on the arm and used its gravity vector to calculate the angle. It worked really well and we didn’t have to worry about calibrating it if we tinkered with the arm (like we’ve had to do a few times with the Rev Through-bore we’re using this year).
